content.title: Duplex Ultrasound
content.definition: Duplex ultrasound combines B-mode (2D grayscale) imaging with Doppler flow assessment (spectral and color) to provide both anatomic and hemodynamic information about blood vessels, serving as the primary non-invasive diagnostic tool in vascular surgery.

components.b_mode: Two-dimensional grayscale imaging of vessel anatomy
components.color_doppler: Color-coded representation of flow direction and velocity
components.power_doppler: Amplitude-based flow detection (sensitive for slow flow)

doppler_physics.angle_correction: Must be <60° for accurate velocity measurement
doppler_physics.aliasing: Occurs when velocity exceeds Nyquist limit

waveform_patterns.triphasic: Normal peripheral artery - forward, reverse, forward diastolic
waveform_patterns.biphasic: Mild disease - loss of reverse component
waveform_patterns.tardus_parvus: Proximal stenosis - delayed upstroke, low amplitude

dialysis_access.criteria: Volume flow (<600 mL/min AVG, <400 mL/min AVF concerning)

quality_metrics.accreditation: ICAVL (Intersocietal Commission for Accreditation of Vascular Laboratories)

content.statement: Duplex Ultrasound is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Diagnostics Duplex-Ultrasound that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Duplex Ultrasound helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Duplex Ultrasound include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Duplex Ultrasound.

definitions_glossary.concept: A fundamental idea or notion in the domain
definitions_glossary.property: A characteristic or attribute of an entity
definitions_glossary.relationship: A connection or association between concepts

learning_objectives: Describe components of duplex ultrasound examination
Interpret waveform patterns and their clinical significance
Apply velocity criteria for stenosis grading
clinical_pearls: Angle of insonation must be <60° for accurate velocity measurement
Triphasic waveform is normal in peripheral arteries
ICA PSV >230 cm/s indicates ≥70% carotid stenosis
Compression non-compressibility is diagnostic for DVT

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
